biogHist.abstract: The Child Welfare Department of Western Australia was responsible for the welfare of children in out of home care for much of the twentieth century. Known as the 'CWD' or 'the welfare', the department had an impact on the lives of many WA families. The CWD ran its own Children's Homes, 'placed' children in other Children's Homes or Foster Homes and organised adoptions. It licensed and inspected the places and people who were registered to provide care and kept statistics on the number of children who were in care. The CWD also had the power to bring children before the Children's Court.
biogHist.p: The State Records Office website gives an overview of the history of the Child Welfare Department:

' In 1927 the State Children Act Amendment Act was passed changing the name of the principal Act and the State Children's Department to Child Welfare Act and Child Welfare Department respectively. Responsibility for the Child Welfare function remained with the Chief Secretary until 1931 when it was passed to the Minister for Mines.
In 1934 a separate portfolio was created for child welfare. The Child Welfare Department was abolished in 1972 and its functions passed to the newly created Department for Community Welfare.'

Until 1972, the Child Welfare Department shared responsibility for the 'care and control' of children who were 'Aboriginal Wards' with the Chief Protector of Aborigines, and later the Commissioner for Native Affairs and the Commissioner of Native Welfare. I

Sydney Watson had been the Secretary (head) of the Child Welfare Department for its first 15 years when he retired in 1932 after 37 years service. The department's Annual Report of that year described Mr Watson's contribution as follows:

'His successful efforts in improving legislation for the protection of children and those in distress, his unfailing courtesy, keen sympathy, and practical help, have won, not only well merited appreciation, but better still, have left behind as the outcome of his official career a lasting tribute of better conditions to many in need.'

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Ngal-a Mothercraft Home and Training Centre Inc (1956 - 1989)

descriptiveNote.p: The Child Welfare Department placed all children under the age of six years at Ngal-a Mothercraft Home and Training Centre Inc (Ngala) from 1 September 1959 (and possibly earlier) instead of the Child Welfare Reception Home.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children

archref.unittitle: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children
archref.abstract: Minutes of conference of representatives of institutions accommodating migrant children' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It gives insight into the process of migrating children to Australia from Britain, and the inspection of their welfare after they arrive.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Child Welfare Department, Perth, 1930

archref.repository: Truth newspaper collection, State Library of Western Australia
archref.unitid: State Library of Western Australia Call Number 10028B/2024
archref.abstract: This is a digitised copy of an image of glass negative and is part of the Truth newspaper collection held at the State Library of Western Australia. The image shows the outside of the building that housed the Child Welfare Department in 1930. The image was made available by the Historical Records Rescue Consortium Project supported by Lotterywest.
archref.note: For personal use only. To publish or display, contact the State Library of Western Australia

descriptiveNote.p: Include in Gallery

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Methodist Homes for Children

archref.unittitle: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Methodist Homes for Children
archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia. This excerpt from the letter refers to pocket money for British child migrants at the Methodist Homes for Children.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Health Examinations

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia. The letter gives a brief summary of the types of health examinations that were planned to be undertaken in institutions receiving child migrants from Britain after World War Two. These institutions were the Anglican Homes (Swan Homes), the Methodist Home for Children, Fairbridge Farm School and the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association. An example of the letter sent to all institutions is included in this excerpt from the file.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Moss Report Implementation [Excerpt] - Case Histories

archref.abstract: This is an excerpt from the digital copy of the John Moss Report on Child Migration - Implementation of Recommendations from the National Archives of Australia website. It is a letter from the Child Welfare Department in Western Australia. The letter gives a brief summary of the types of 'case history' information that was sent to the institutions receiving child migrants from Britain after World War Two. These institutions were the Anglican Homes (Swan Homes), the Methodist Home for Children, Fairbridge Farm School and the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964

archref.repository: State Law Publisher of Western Australia
archref.unittitle: Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964
archref.abstract: The Adoption of Children Act Amendment Act 1964 contained a number of amendments designed to 'modernise' the laws relating to adoption in Western Australia and to harmonise adoption laws across Australia.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians

archref.unittitle: Happy and Carefree Natures Caught By the Cameraman In These Studies of Young Western Australians
archref.abstract: This is a picture from the Sunday Times newspaper, which is published on the National Library of Australia's website, 'Trove'. It shows a small boy who is being 'offered' for adoption. He is included with three other children in an article seeking adoptive parents for children who were wards of the state.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Their Home a Garage

archref.abstract: This is a picture from The Daily News, which is published on the National Library of Australia's website, 'Trove'. It shows a little girl and her baby brother. In the article, the Child Welfare Department (CWD) was appealing for someone to be their foster-parent. The CWD regularly used articles like this to encourage people to become foster parents. Advertisements continue to be used in the early twenty-first century, but children's identities are protected.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Boys Behind Iron Bars

archref.abstract: This is a picture from an article in the Sunday Times newspaper, which is published on the National Library of Australia's website, 'Trove'. The picture shows the 'solitary confinement' wing' of the Child Welfare Reception Home at Mt Lawley, where 'delinquent' children were housed. The article condemned this practice and called for better facilities.
